column12: B1: As if I was part of a Monet painting. I was a little girl in a long white drass and a ribbon smelling the flowers. H6: I was a ballerina doing point.
column17: Not a story, just me being present in the moment and moving to the music.

column12: B: Images of dancers -- during several movements of the Beethoven as well as bright colours clashing. H: During the Hough -- one of the movements brought thoughts of bees buzzing and/or flies making a drone-like sound

column12: Remembering when I played the piece myself

column12: I had images of free growing things like vines over tranquil pools. The scene was both peaceful and full of life. There seemed both prompted by memories of willow and also entirely newly created within my mind.
column17: I had visions of traffic, panicky between the bustle of vehicles and people and the more quiet byways along the sides
column21: Initially, I found that I most experienced colors,  forming across my violins in gentle, hailed streams. Of course, mundane thoughts invaded, but later I had more concrete images as well

column12: Reminded me of the wind storm night this week, and trying to sleep through it and the dog keeping me up all night
column17: A drifting, wandering mindset- upbeat and flowing-- like a walk through a beautiful area on a relaxing weekend.

column12: No long memory, but a lot of memories about highsehod things (1981-05)
column17: I had no fictional memories

column12: Visiting grocery markets in Paris with my late grandmother. Some of the music made me think of vendors shouting out their wares.
column17: Contemplation of sad things- the current state of the world, especialy war, death and grief

column12: The sprightly manner in which the Takacs played the first movement brought to mind a specific memory. My wife and I were walking on a hillside in the Adivondad region of NY State when we came upon a swarm of dragon flies flying around each other in a sunny spot. There were dozens of them, never leaving that sunny spot for as long as we gazed at them. All the same species. They seemed to be enjoying each other.
column17: The death scene from Romeo and Juliette, which I have heard Beethoven had in mind when he wrote this movement. The music perfectly fits this scene, so it is not difficult to imagine it during this movement.
column21: The last movement of the Hough had a very striking musical depiction of laughter, among the best I have heard from any composer.

column12: Thought about an old high-school friend. Recalled how he went to trade school & began contemplating his continued existence in the same hometown he grew up in. Had a blue-collared attitude -- him & the friends he used to hang out with. Appreciated his friendship, but never felt too close to him. It's an obtuse thought.
column17: Thought up a story about a woman who makes the internal vow to write the longest poem she can. She's a mother with one young daughter, and I envisioned them in a living room setting. She's trying to write lines, while her daughter draws next to her.

column12: Honestly, was imagining the section of "A gentleman in Moscow" "Cabarat" Secrat grande section
column17: Personal conversation

column12: -Street scenes -Moods related to personal interactions -Anticipation of musical direction
column17: Walk thorugh natural scenes

column12: The Beethoven seemed to begin as a frolic on a beautiful summer's day. Dancing, conversing, enjoying the overtures, eated on the glrass in a partk. Noice surrounds with the awrmth of the sun, twittering insects, butterflies, and swaying of trees. Couples begin to pair off as theiy paster lovingly more intimate conversations as the day pose slowly to noon and eventually to sunset and evening
column17: The story enters the lobby of a hotel where a set of actions take place. People checking in and out, discussions arise in the lobby some pleasant other full of disturbance and anxiety. The hotel is forcefully ending with crying. Staff and guests. There is continued action and nothing is resolved, there is never a ___, pure chaos.

column12: I remember performing with a trio and the interaction of my fellow performers.
column17: The composer's discussion prior to the performance started me thinkin gabout marionettes etc, and the more lurid aspects of paris int he 20s.

column12: Events in my life - planning how to navigate the times ahead
column21: I don't omagine fiction to music...

column12: No doubt because the piece is programmatic, prompted with being "au pare" in Paris, I thought of summer 2022, visiting my good friend who lived in Paris at that time. Extremely hot summer, one of the first things we did was take a bottle of champagne to a park; hot sun, another oocasion, in the tuilleries, also hot...
column17: Nope, I was entirely engrossed in the music, apart from the thoughts of the hot summer in Paris. The comments from Hugh at the beginning made me try to imagine marionettes and whatnot, and car horns in the first movement, but by and large I was focused on the performance.

column12: Beethoven - sublime beauty - water or light patterns Hough - gestures of musicians

Though the memory I thought of was not the longest sustained, it was the most intense. I imagined practicing a Beethoven Sonata in B-flat, I think when I was younger and in music school. I could almost feel my fingers twitching as I listened, and the environment of the old practice room was vivid.
column17: I specifically imagined the black and white depictions of Paris from some children's book, but I can't remember the name. I just saw drawings of French buildings made o fblack crayon on white paper. Also I smell cucumber sandwiches??? Don't know if they are connected
column21: In the final movement of the Hough, I saw wheat fields; along with blue sky, green trees, etc. But very golden,  autumnal wheat fields.

column12: It's a memory of a short story I just read today (by Chuck Palahniuk) There were also memories of the previous concert I attended
column17: Everyday life scenarios - I just imagined the different ways to enjoy the weekend. I also pictured the scenes from a poem I'm doing resesarch on
column21: Beethoven's Adagio was very striking in its sobriety. Most of my memories were elicited by visual cues, as I have never listened to these pieces before. Aside from memories, I spent the most time thinking about research

column12: I was thinking a lot about my grandparents, who introduced me to classical music, which has become a very important part of my life. I was thinkin gabout spending time at Tanglewood with them, listening to great music in a beautiful outdoor setting.
column17: I was imagining Parisians strolling by - women with fancy hats - dogs - remembering the architecture of the city
column21: The hotel movement where things start off ok and then descend into what made me think of a funhouse, was difficult - the composer's explanation of the piece plunged me into worry over the current state of our country. I might not have gone there had it not been for the insight into the time period (pre WWII) that inspired the piece.

column12: This movement very closely resembled the modern era soundtrack in my favorite computer game, Civilization IV. It brought back memories of playing the game- building modern era infrstructure such as airports and factories, having workers turn roads into railrods, and moving large stacks of combat units around to capture other civilizations.
column17: I heard this piece last summer (or perhaps the year before) at the Marlboro Music Festival. It made me think back to summers in Vermont and a feeling of me floating through a beautiful summer day with clear skies, animal sounds, and lots of green vegetation.

column12: Not a memory but evolution of atmosphere of early Romantic era, perhaps near Venice this Beethoven is much more settled in his culture (like Brhams) rather than an outsider at where his daughters and relationships to previous.
column17: Imagining conversation between Hugh and Poulenc. Sharing jokes and pondering observations about society as in some Poulenc song cycles  (j'ai vie mes amies sans souces).
column21: Enjoying the sense of family among performers- string quartet almost uniquely exists only as and lohen the 4 conspire in real time to bring the mediocre parts into an organic state. Frquent how they imagine the white case when first reading their parts (Do they all see all parts first or want to first throguh)

column12: B2: I remembered the very relaxing and positive images from my trip the week before to Austin, TX. H1: The music most vividly reminded me of being on the boulevard Champs Elyseea in Paris 50 years ago.
column17: I was able to imagine what were complexities of the life at that time - maybe as we view them in retrospect- and made more vivid and intense by knowing what was to come.
column21: Hough movement 5 also evoked very strong emotions-- sadness

column12: A boy aged about four, who when he heard a cello for the first time burst into tears with heavy sobs. Then, almost immediately, a memory, about the other end up life: my grandmother. At a concert she knew would probably be the last she would ever attend, bursting into tears. The music was Beethoven's ninth symphony.
column17: Divers theatrical characters strutting and getting on a stage.

column12: Rowing on the small pond in the Bois de Boulogne with my husband. It was sunny and not windy. The water moved slowly around the boat. Watching the small "taxi" ferry restaurant guests for the Sunday dejeuner to the guitar looking restaurant on the pond and small island.
column17: This was suggested by composer Hough's introduction, describing what he had in mind when he wrote this piece. I imagined the hustle of pedestrains, carriages and horses on a wide Paris boulevard. Not stalling, rather the move - memory prusues with purpose, with much intent to go to their destinations.
column21: When the Beethoven piece began, I was ____ how I feel this space is a peaceful protected interior. In particular, these days very much away from current news and the dreadful MAGAs. I seriously wonder (am convinced) no MAGAs enter here. Thankfully!

column12: I didn't experience memories. I'm listening to the music.
column13: I wasn't imagining. I was listening to the music.

column12: I had no memories. I was at this concert because I love this quartet and their interpretation of Beethoven. I was entirely absorbed by the music, its structure and development. If I wanted to daydream, I would have stayed at home!
column17: No fictional imaginings at all! I don't really understand these questions. Listening to music is totally absorbive and immersive. I think I'm the wrong subject for your research! None - no imaginings!

column12: I play the violin and have played reguarly with a string quartet that sight read every Saturday morning. The first movement of the Beethoven brought back many memories of this great repertorie. That I no longer have as I have moved.
column17: My great-grandmother was an accomplished artist and did several drawings that look like late 19th century/early 20th century Paris. This music made me imagine this Paris.

column12: I rememnbered someone a couple of years behind me in grade school (~1950) and the house where she lived, then when a US senator of the same family anme came to my parents house for a social occasion - drinks before lunch, I think. I have no idea why I should remember this! No other thoughts. This was during the Beethoven probably movement 2, maybe 3. The most coherent vision was of the bridge over the Charles River on the road to this person's house (a house I never visited, but I knew where it was).
column17: I had no fictional imaginings, I had some thoughts about the Hough quartet - which movement was being played, could I remember the titles? But I didn't envision them.

column12: The whole first half was in the UK for me, even though I've never been there! Beethoven mvmt 1 conjured a memory of my brother (this one part wasn't in the uk) learning to crawl on Easter day years ago, crawlling for a plate of sweet tarts that ended up on the floor, then it went to Beatrix Potter Peter Cottontail Morie and its pastels. Then what I imagined when I read Wuthering Heights - rainy hills of heather. At adagio, an image of rain pouring down a wood-framed window. Hough was fountains! All over, coming up from the concrete. I guesss the concrete was at Cinderella's castle. Also some of the movemets brought me to a vide of Darcy Bussel dancing the ballet Prince of the Pagolas Red & graig.

Nope again, the sun will always lone, even at the darkest age

The spinning of traditional Chinese dance as the spinning and up rising of the violin at each of the dynamics of the cello is the turning of each dance character, as through from violets to homogenous as I first scared of fault at which I found exteremely joy in it, and then everything seems to change, or somehow too shortly, as strech my leg over the top of my head and appears the innocent smile last time to the audience, the quoartet ends, al my dance ended at them seven. column12: The second movement of Beethoven's String Quartet in F Major is emotional and has deep feeling. The first movement is full of energy, so is the last movement. Hough's slow movements are dramatic and has strong dynamic changes. The fast movements are vivid and has a lot of details also.
column17: When I listen to music, I usually don't imagine any fictional story or scene. I just purely enjoy the music.

column12: B3: it brought back my memory of my first year of undergrad when my quartet was working on Mendelssohn's quartet No.2 (also the scherzo mvt). column12: First falling in love with Beethoven's string quartet because of a film. I was making at the time, in 2022 -- 14th string quartet was my first love -- worked backwards -- wrote the film in March of 2022 with thoughts of summer -- this movement, while not in the film, exhibited the character or expression I wished to capture -- reminds me of a time filled with hope and excitement at the opportunity to make films, sitting in a cabin in the Pocons snowed in, dreaming of sunnier days
column17: Always bad with melody one memory of music, but I took note of a film I'd like to make, about two sisters figuring out a way to convince their father to rejoin the living after becoming a recluse following the death of his wife, their mother. The scene is tense because the younger sister, who lives with the father, is less optimistic than the older sister, who feels like she has all the answers (she doesn't, which she will soon find out).
column21: I'm excited to re-experience the Hough string quartet, as this was my first experience.

column17: The Beethoven-inspired "imaginings" come largely from my own emotions and musical impressions. Also more abstract. Images during the Hough were more vivid -- I was also thinking/engaged more by the music in the Beethoven, and had more attention in the Hough to let my mind wander. Imagined scenes during the Hough were largely led by the movement titles, but images/scenes easily followed.

I spent a lot of time looking at the musicians, and their expressions and body movements, their smiles and shared looks, and how they felt the music they were playing. I can hear the music on the radio, but I only experience it as played by artists here!

column12: None of the memories lasted long enough for me to take real notice of - very much passing thoughts

column12: for some reason in the second movement of the first piece I thought of a childhood friend with whom I am not in touch anymore. Although today is the anniversary of my mother's death.

column21: None of these elicited anything to me other than cacophonous annoyance... column12: Remember the warmth and sunlight of a garden in Aix-en-Provence. Also the smells of flowers and heat coming off the Earth. And the olive trees.

column12: Memories of being on the beach and of sailing. Walking on the deck with crisp air and comfortable breezes. My shawl blowing in the breeze. Feeling calm + relaxed but also like I could do anything. Hopeful + content at the same time.
column17: One of the Hough movements made me clearly imagine 2 or more people fighting, arguing.

column12: It was playing in orchestra. Trying to learn cello fingering. The disappointment that I didn't want to practice. And that in 6th grade our school had a guess where we'd end up. Mine was a concert cellist (I'm not).
column17: I imagined being in a set of a BBC/PBS period piece filmed in France. The greenery- the women in long shirts, etc.
column21: Plucking - my dad used to say "you shouldn't pluck" (he was a judgemental Brit) - and how much I enjoyed it

column12: 1) Wailing of violins in concert halls, with wet pavement outside - from Paul Jennings, British columnist & humanist, noted for "oddly" book series.   2) Mud pots, bubbling upwards (i.e. geothermal type.     3) Small groupings of small birds, flying up &down inside a cavernous old brick faculty building (the type with ranks & ranks of small windows) birds are seeking a window from which to escape, unsuccessfuly.     4) Tightly modulated scales of music like viewing a finely mandolined large vegetable such as a cucumber, with the stack of slides sliding diagonally into the scales

column17: I imagined a dinner table that all around sat robots instead of people. There was no food or drink and the robots were large and boxy like a child's halloween costume, they weren't speaking, just moving in a "robotic" way in small jerky movements.

column12: I was thinking about my experience/ memory walking on the Washington Bridge and looking over to the frozen Lake Carnegie. This is a thing I do almost daily, so I recently I have been staring/seeing the frozen lake everyday. I recalled the cracks and blemishes on the ice surface (and thought about what would it be like to walk on them). Somehow this movement made me a bit cold.
column17: This movement conjured a field of flowers in my mind. More specifically, it's an open field of grass with lots of small flowers (daisies, buttercups perhaps). I also imagined a clear sky in the background.

column12: A long time ago I heard this piece for the first time. Went in one ear and out the other. Same (mostly) the other times I've heard it. This time I was shattered. It was beatifully played, true but more, I'm old and hearing this and feeling my heart breaking, I realized something I hadn't quite before. You change much faster when you're old than when you're young.
column21: Just a thought. Does the knowledge that you'll be writing about something cause you to think differently during the performance? How would you test this in your reserach? I don't have any good ideas.

column21: I thought about musical compositions almost the whole time. What to do, and violin, and how. Imagining different direction; contrasts of high/low, long/short, soft/loud, many/few. How to learn from Beethoven - how to imagine the Hough! Taking personal notes on how to compose, if I were to try.

column12: The music felt babbly, which made me think of champagne - which made me think of dinking champagne with my wife the weekend we became engaged. We received a gift of two beautiful champagne flutes and a bottle, and a friend took a photo of us through one of the filled, fizzing, glasses. The music evoked that fizzy, bubbly, happy moment for me.
